document.text: W ho W ill You V ote F or V ir gin ian s Halifax, Va., Sept. 26th., Speaking before a tremendous and enthusiastic audience -at Halifax this afternoon Con gressman H. D. Flood created a sensation by reading a letter from Judge George J. Hundley, of Farmville, addressed to the chairman of the Democratic S t a t e Central Committee, charging that Colonel Henry W. Anderson, in an address de livered at Farmville on August 30tb, had expressed himself as ashamed of the star in the United States flag which repre sented the State of Virginia. This astounding disclours fell as a thunder bolt upon the voters of the Fifth District who were present at the speaking. The letter, signed by Judge Hundley, the oldest circuit judge in Virginia, was written under date of September 9th. It was in reply to a communi cation from J. N. Brenaman, secretary of the Democratic State Committee. It reads in full, as follows Office of Geo. J. Hundley, Judge of the Fifth Judicial Cir cuit of Virginia. Farmville, Va , Sept. 9,1921. Hon. J. N. Brenaman, Sect. Democratic Committee, Richmond Va. My dear Mr. Brenaman Yours of the 6 th instant re ceived, and I write you, as ac curately as I can, what occur- at the time of Colonel Ander sons speech at Farmville. I note that you say the incident may be used by the committee. I have no objection to your using it,provided it is not based alone upon my statement, for it has been made public. It was published in the Farm ville Herald, and quoted and commented on by the Lynch burg News. I intended that it should be come buplic property, and that there should be no issue of veracity between him and my self, so I repeated to him what he had said, in the presence of the audience, and asked him if 1 had understood him correctly, and he admitted it. He saidWhen he was in the Balkans, trying to help and uplift those miserable people, he carried on the front of his automobile,the American Flag, and the women and chil dren would ccme up and kiss the flag, but that he was really ashamed to let them do this, for he felt that he was practic ing a fraud upon them, to al low them to kiss a flag having upon it a star representing the State of Virginia whose gov ernment was so unrepublican, so despotic, and so disgraceful as that of the State of Virginia. I waited quietly, until he closed, but before the audience dispersed, called upon him to explain thii.t statement, repeat ing what 1 had understood him to say. He did not deny it, but admitted it, with an awkward attempt to explain and which did not explain at all. I did not discuss anything with him but contented myself with Bay ing, Col. Anderson, there are men here who followed the flag of Virginia for four years in the Givil War, and those who fought for that Flag of ours in France, and shed their blood for it, and I want to say for them, that in all our history, there never has been a time, and there never will be a time, whilst the sun shines, that such a thing, as you have said, could be true of the Star repre senting our glorious old State on the Flag of our Common Country. W ith kind regards and best wishes, I am, Yours sincerely, Geo. J. Hundley. Judge Hundley, who presides over the fifth judicial circuit, is a veteran Virginia jurist and a veteran of the Givil War. He has a son, Lieutenant Robert G. Hundley, who saw service on the fighting front in France. Judge Hundley enlisted first with the Albemarle Howitiers, after which he served with the Fifth Vsrginia Infantry. He resigned from this regiment to enter the cavalry, in which arm of the service he remained until the close of the war be tween the states. He was seriously wounded while lead ing a cavalry charge. Lieutenant Robert G. Hund ley, also a war veteran, spilled bis blood in France in defense of the Stars and Stripes. His record was a brilliant one. He served with Company B., 306th Infantry, 77th Army Division with Company F., 120th Infan try, 30th Division, and with Company B., of the 369th New York. This latter regiment was brigaged with troops in the 161st French Army Divis ion, Fourth French Army. Lieutenant Hundley, who is now stumping for the Demo cratic ticket, was deeperately wounden in the campaign offensive on September 30th., 1918. Four major operations were performed on him and for some time his life was diapaired of. He saw eleven months active service in the Western front in France.

document.text: The Senatorial Convention Nominates H. D. Flood by AcclamationThe Buckingham and Cumberland Dem ocrats Nominate E. W. Hubard for the House of DelegatesSenator Martin Endorsed. Promptly at the appointed hour, Chairman V. E. Pratt, of the Buck ingham Democracy, called to order the convention of the Eighteenth senatorial district Iu the courthouse ou Monday. The convention organ ized by electing Dr. Pratt chairman and W. W. Haskins secretary. This organization was made permanent. The chair appointed the follow ing committee on credentials Frank Moon, of Buckingham Paul Pettit, f Fluvanna Joel Watkins, of Ap pomattox. The committee reported!he fol lowing delegates present and end- lied to stats in the convention BuckinghamFailed to get the names of these delegates. AppomattoxJoel Watkins, A. II. Clement, James B. Abbitt, II. 8. Coleman, A. B. Thornhill, J. W. Davidson, W. F. Wright. FluvannaA. A. Gray, Paul Pet- dt, C. B. Wood, W. C. White, W. F. Snead. Mr. A. A. Gray, of Fluvanna, then nominated Hon. H. D. Flood to suc ceed himself as Senator from this district, iu a speech which was well received, by the audience, and which elicited much applause, showing plainly that the audience endorsed his eulogistic remarks on Mr. Flood and his record as a representative. Mr. Gray is a pleasant speaker, aud his remarks were timely and highly appreciative. Mr, A. B. Thornhill, of Appomat tox, in a beautiful speech, seconded the nomination of Mr. Flood. He referred to the magnanimity with which Mr. Flood refused the certifi cate of election to Congress in 1896, and presented figures showing that iie received 4,000 more votes than diu Mr. Tucker in 1894, and 6,000 more than did Mr. Quarles in 1898. Mr. Thornhills remarks made a good impressiou, and he was the re cipient of congratulations upon his peech. Messrs. F. C. Moon and Ednt. W. Hubard, ou the part of Bucking ham, made short speeches seconding the nomination. At the conclusion of these speech es Mr. Paul Pettit moved that the nomination be made by acclamation, which was adopted, and the chair appointed Messrs. Gray, Thornhill, and Hubard to iuform Mr. Flood of his nomination, and to present him to the convention. Mr. Flood accepted the nomina tion in a speech of twenty minutes, which aroused much enthusiasm. He assured the peopie of his appie- fiaaou of the honor conferred, and of their endorsement and loyalty, to him and his public acts. He spoke earnestly of the faithful service to the laboring people of Virginia ren dered by Senator Martin, aud of the light he made for him in the Demo cratic caucus six years ago, assuring the Democracy of Virginia that, if- they would lay the mantle of the seuatorship upon Mr. Martin at that time, the Democracy of the Old Do minion would approve their action. Mr. Flood referred to the large ma jority of counties having gone for Senator Martin as proving the truth of his prediction, and said that Mr. Martin would be renominated by a four-fifths majority. At the con clusion of his speech he was pre sented wit-h a bouquet of beautiful flowers. Mr. F. 0. Moon offered the follow ing resolutions, which weie unani mously adopted Resolved, That the course of Hon. T. S. Martin, United States Senator, is fully endorsed and approved and the nomiuee of this convention is in structed to vote for and support Him for re-election to that position. . 2d, That the tiominee of this con vention is instructed to vote for and support Hon. George J. Hundley for re-electiou as Judge of this judicial circuit. Mr. W. W. Haskins said that he was instructed by the Maysville-dis- trict meeting to bring up the ques tion of moving the courthouse aud the nominee was instructed to op pose any movement looking to the removal of the courthouse. The senatorial convention then adjourned, and the house conven tion, composed of delegates from Buckingham and Cumberland, as sembled for the purpose of nomi nating a candidate for the House of Delegates. Dr. Pratt and Mr. Haskins were retained as chairman and secretary, respectively, of the convention.  W. M. Smith, of Cumberland, and F. C. Moon, of Buckingham, were appotiled a committee on creden tials, who reported the following delegates present and entitled to scats in the cony.epjbj.Qn t CumberlandW. if. South, H. D. Woodson. H. K. Adams, E. B. Davis, A. B. Armstrong, and J. W. Adams. BuckinghamWe are nnable to give the names of these delegates. F. C. Moon uommated Hon. E. W. Ilubar.t for delegate to the General Assembly from tjiis district, com posed of Buckingham an,d Cumber land counties, Mr. W. M. Smith, of Cumberland, in a few well chosen remarks, sec onded the nomination. Mr. John W. Adams moved that it be made by acclamation, which was done with a whoop. Sfr. Hubard was informed of his nonuuatiQQ, and was presented to the convention for a speech. Mr. Hubard made onj ?fp t his h.ap-i py speeches, full of logic and rea-! sou. He was severe on independ ents, and promised that the flag of Democracy should not trail in the dust, aud predicted a great victory fojt tjie party at the general election. He appealed ty his hearers with much force io si an cl by fthe nomi nees, saying it was not now afight, of Flood and Hubard, but a fight for the supremacy of Democratic

document.text: THE JUDGESHIP CONTEST IN THE TH CIRCUIT. To the General Assembly of Vir ginia, In obedience to law it will be your duty to elect a successor to judge George J. Hundley as Judge of the Fifth Judicial Circuit, and it is with pleasure and confidence that we. the nndersignea resident and practicing attorney 8 in the Cir cuit present, the claims of Judge Hundley for re election. For seven years he haB presided over our Court and by his courageous, im partial and efficient discharge of duty and dispatch of business, lie has won laurels and added dignity to the judicial ermine, and his name will form a strong connect ing link in the chain of  irginiaa distinguished Judiciary.  As evi dence of his eminent fitness and qualifications for the position, we refer with pride to the fact that during seven years administration of justice, he has only been re versed four tims. Judge Hundley is a man of ability, experience and culture a first class lawyer, aid we hope the time will never come in Virginia when the General Assembly will torn out an able and efficient judge simply to give place to an other who wants the office. His R ecord A s a S oldier . He enlisted at the commence meat of the war was a gallant sol dier, serving throughout the war, and was dangerously wounded in battle. His R ecord A s a C itizen . At the close of the war he com menced the practice of law and soon attained high rank in his pro fession. He has been a .lifelong Democrat and as such served in the House of Delegates and Senate of Virginia and until his electon as Judge was one of the most active and efficient State canvassers for the Democratic party. The accom panying papers will demonstrate tha be is overwhelmingly the choioe of the bar, officers of court and people in the Circuit, and we confidently rely upon his re-election in accordance with precedent under such circumstances, and as a jus tribute to merit and worth. E. W. H dbard , Commonwealths Attorney of Buckingham. W m . M. S mith , Commonwealths Attorney and late County Judge of Cumberland, Vo. A. H. C lement , of Appomattox bar. A. B. A rmstro  o , of Prince Ed ward bar. We pnblish as a matter of news the above petition signed by a com mittee representing, as we are in formed more than three-fourths of the resident bar of this Circuit and about seven-eighths of all the law yers practicing in this cncuit. It is no secret that an effort is being made in certain quarters to defeat the reelection of Judge Handley and this is the response of the law yers. What have the people of Aj pomattox to say on this important subject? Perhaps if Judge H und ley is to be defeated they will wain to know the reason why. The peo ple do not elect their judges di rectly, but they do elect the men who elect the judges. The lawyer are not the only people interested it the election of capable, impartial and fearless judgesjudges who have the honesty and the courage ti administer law without respect to persons and before whom all men stand upon a level so long as they obey the laws of the land. The election of Governors and Senators is very important, but these are far removed from the people. Thei judges touch them more nearly than any other officials, No man can estimate the harm that a weak and oscilating judgeone courting the favor of men of power and influence, may do, aud in such cases it is the good, plain, indus trious people w ho suffer. The law yers know the law and can protect themselves in a measure, but the plain people want to feel when they fie down to sleep at night that a fearless, independent and upright judge stands between them and all wrong and injustice. Thank God, the people are free once more, since the shadow of negro domination is removed far from them, and we are about to return to the old order of things, when politicians were the servants and not the masters of the people. Perhaps the people may aak candidate for the Legislature. How are you going to vote on the Judgeship question? or they may even dare to instruct their driegate Who knows?

document.text: The Campaign Opened The Democratic State Cam paign will be opened formally at Clintwood, Dickinson ooun ty, September 27, when the Hon. E. Lee Trinkle, party gubernatorial nominee, will ad dress the voters of that section on campaign issues by deliver ing his key note address. Congressman H. D. Flood, state democratic chairman, is booked to address the voters of Halifax at Halifax September 26th. Chairman Flood will speak at Middlesex the follow ing day and at Amherst on October 10th. As the Demo cratic campaign is largely under the direction of the State chairman Mr. Flood will be kept busily engaged daring the next few weeks. The Tenth district congressman h a s thrown himself very heartily into the fight and is confident of leading the democratic forces to an overwhelming victory. Speaking assignments are now being mapped out for Senator Swanson,Senator Glass Governor Westmoroland Davis, as well as all of the Virginia members of Congress. Robert G. Hnndley, veteran of the World War and a son of Judge George J. Hundley, of the cirouit benob, will .deliver an address at Cumberland Court Honse September 27 th.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: Senatorial C onvention. The senatorial convention for tie 18th district met a t . Buckinghari Courthouse ou Friday, Septembei 20. R. S. Ellis, chairman of th Democratic committee of Bucking ham county, called the convention to order promptly at 11 oclock a . m The permanent orgonization was ef fected by electing Sam L. Fergusoi chairman, and Win. R. Silvey seem taiy. Mr. Ferguson made a grace ful speech, thanking the conventioi for the honor, and made a strong plea for harmony. He now declared the convention ready for the trans action of business, and named tb- following committees Ou Creden tialsP. P. Glover, T. W. Trent and Judge Wtod on Resolutions R. S. Ellis, J. B. Abbitt, and W. White. The convention suspended any further proceedings, awaiting the rtports of the committees. I 11 a short while the chairman of the Committee on Credentials mad- the following report, which wa- _ adopted That jwe find no coutests, oiid thatHTTof the delegates present dad all those represented by proxies were duly elected. The chair then announced that nominations were in order, whereupon M. L. A. Moseley, of Buckingham, presented the name of F. C. Moon. Judge A. 8 . Hall, of Buckingham, presented the name of W. P. Ellis- Seconding speeches were made by Samuel L Ferguson and Dr. Randolph, The roll was called with the following result Appomattoxthirteen for Moon  Buckinghamnine for Ellis, three for Moon Fluvannaeight fo- Moon giving Mr. Moon the uomi nation on drat ballot. Mr. Moons nomination was made unanimous. Toe chair appointed Judge A. S. Hall, Judge Wood, and R. C. Chi! dress a committee to notify Messrs. Moon and Ellis of the result of tb- vote. While waiting for the action of this committee, the chairmau of the Committee on Resolutions pre sented the following preamble and resolutions, which were adopted Whereas the whole people of the Third judicial circuit of Virginia us well as of the State at large recog nize the popularity of Judge George J. Hundley as a Christian gentleman of the highest type, a jurist preemi nently noted for industry, discrimi nating ability as a lawyer, fairness to litigants, and courtesy to the bar. and a- a life-long Democrat there fore, be it Resolved, 1 , That the Democrats of the Senatorial Convention of the Eighteenth Senatorial District of Virginia, in convention assembled, do hereby endorse Judge Hundlev for reelection, and instruct the nom inee of this convention to vote for him in the election before the Gen eral Assembly. 2 , That we, the Democrats of the Eighteenth Senatorial District, in convention assembled, most heartilr endorse the course of Hon. II. D. Flood as our representative in the Senate of Virginia, who, by his abil ity, his untiring devotion to the best interests of the Commonwealth, and his eloquence in the espousal of the ,right, and in condemnation of what was wrong and hurtful, justly earn ed for himself the enviable reputa tion of being one of the ablest and most eloquent representatives in the Senate of Virginia, which this grand old Commonwealth could point to with pleasure and pride. 3, That we extend our heartfelt sympathy to the widow of the late President William McKinley m this time of her great affliction, and also to his kindred and we congratulate ourselves that the character of our late President was such as the whole nation might well be proud of and we hereby call upon our representa tive in Congress to assist in framing such laws as will rid our country of

document.text: nom inated for Governor of Virginia by the Democratic Convention at Roanoke. At tho evening session of the demooratlo State convention Hon. J. Hoge Tyler, of Pulaski, was nominated by acclamation for Governor of Virginia. The convention was called to order at noon by Gen. George J. Hundley, of Amelia coun ty, acting chairman of the State central com mlttee. The Academy of Music was packed from pit to the highest gallery with dele gates and visitors, and on the stage wero Senators Daniel and Martin. Every Com gressman In the State, State Senators, mem- bers of the House of Delegates, and nearly every democratlo politician of prominence In Virginia. In calling the convention to or der, General Hundley made a short and happy speech, in which be announoed the temporary officers of the convention. The convention at 5 oclock took a reoess until 8 oclock. When the convention reassembled at 8 oclook Mr. Carter Gloss, editor ol the Lynch burg News, placed in nomination for Gov ernor Hon. J. Hoge Tyler, of Pulaski, the mention of whose name was the signal for loud and continued applause. Mr. Glass said, among other things, that Major Tyler would go into tho gubernatorial office a democrat and remain a democrat, which re mark seemed to be understood as a hit at Governor OFerral, and was received with loud and long-continued applause. Prof. Gecrge W. Miles, of Badford, seconded the nomination of Major Tyler for Governor In a short speech, alter which Hon. J. Taylor Ellyson, a candidate for the gubernatorial nomination, moved that Major Tyler be nominated by acclamation, which was done.

Funeral services for th beloved jurist were hold Saturday afternoon at 280 at the Charlotte Court House Presbyterian church, Burial wm in the churchyard. . II  y._ Judge Hutcheson became ill Dec ember 21 during Jhe December tans of court at farmville. After treat ment at the Southaide  hospital at Farmville, he returned to Charlotte Court Houae, IThe esteemed Judge hraa born in 1878, the son of Robert F. and Mary Barkadble Hutcheson. Re gradua ted from Hampden-Sydhey College in 1898. After teaching school for several yean, ha studied law at Washington and Lee University. He began the practice of hit profession at Charlotte Court House, Be sef- , ved as a member of the Houseof Delegatee for one term, j.918-20.He was appointed judge o f the Fifth Judicial Circuit in May, 1-929, by the late Governor E. Monday, May 1st, a large and ei - thusiastir, meeting of the citizens and Bar of Charlotte county rs held at the Courthouse, for the pur pose of giving public expression to the very general and united senti ment of the people in Charlotte in the favor of the re-election of Geo. J. Hundley, as his own successor The meeting was called to order by Hon. Bolan Green, late county Judge, ar.d J. C. Carrington. Clerk of the Court was made Chairman, and Leonard Cox Secretary. On motion of C. R. Green, Esq., a committee was appointed to draft resolutions to express the sentiment of the citizens and members of the bar on this matter. This motion was ably seconded by W. C. Car rington, Esq., who paid forcible aud graceful tribute to the ability ur banity arid fairness iu the full dis burse of the important lunctions of his high office, by Judge Hund ley, not only in his relations to tbe members of the Bar, but to the ad vantage of the people generally and tbe promotion of good order and he general interest of the communiiy at large. The Chair appointed the follow ng Jommitee on the Resolutions Maj. R. V. Gains, Hon. H. C. Rice, and Lee W. Morton, on behalf of the cit izens, and C. R. Green and Thomas E. Watkins of the Bar. The Com mittee reported the following 1 reso lutions which were unanimosly vdopied We the citizens of Charlotte County, Virginia, in public meeting assembled, this first day of Muy. 1905, desire to express our appro bation and high appréciai ion of tbe value und faithful service of Honorable George J. Hundley, as the J.idge of the Fifth Judicial Circuit of Virginia, and to commend him to the legislature for re-election to this honorable position, havin the utmost confidence iu his ability integrity aud impartiality in th discharge of the duties of his office. As a chivalrous Christian gentle- mau and a fearless and uprighi Judge, he has met the requiremeuti of the most exacting und we therefore, earnestly request you honorable body to re-elect him io the high position which be adorns Resolved, that a copy of thes resolutions be forwarded to th Times-Dispacch and the News Leader, Charlotte Gazette, an other newspapers of this circui with a .equest for their publieu tion. document.text: HOUSE c o n v e n t i o n  Immediately upon tbe adjourn meut of the Senatorial Convention, the convention composed of dele gates from Cumberland and Buck ingham .to nominate a candidate for the House of Deb-gates was called to order by I.. S. Ellis, chairman ol the Democratic County Committoi of Buckingham. Permanent organ ization was effected by the elect 01 of It. S. Ellis permanent, chairman, and William R. Silvey secretary. There being no contests, those 01 . the list of delegates to the conven tion handed in o file secretary were declared to be entitled to seats in the convention. Nominations being in order, Wm. M. Smith presented the mime of A, B. Armstrong, of Cumberland conn- ty Judge Hall presented the name of C. Hobhouse Patteson, of Buck ingham  and Dr Randolph present ed the name of H- B. Nicholas, of Buckingham. Seconding speeches were made by J. B. Phillips, E. L. Miles, W. W. Hughes, J. W. Adams. The vote was taken, with the fol lowing result Armstrong, 10 Pat teson, 5 Nicholas, 3. On motion of G. W. Pattesop, tj? nomination of A. B, Armstrong was then made unanimous. The obair appointed J, B. Phillips, Judge A. 8 , Hall, and Dr. Randolph a committee to notify the candidates of ti e action of the convention. Resolutions were passed endorsing Judge George J. Hundley, and in structing the dele ate from Buck ingham and Cumberland to support him in the next Legislature. Reso lutions of condolence for the widow and relatives of the late President McKinley were passed j also resojiu tions endorsing the course of lion. E. W. Hubard in the lust, session of the General Assembly. At this time A. B. Amistrong ap peared before the convention, and ! accepted the nomination, pledging lis earnest endeavors 10 a faithful di charge of nis duties, if elected. C. H. Patteson and ii. B. Nicholas also gracefully accepted the situa tion aud bowed in submission to the rill of their fellow-Democrats, and pledged themselves to do all in their power for the success of the ticket.

document.text: Conleds at Brandy Station. Judge George J. Hundley Farm ville, Va. You are cordially invited to at tend the reunion of the Calvary and Horse Artillery of the Armies of Northern Virginia and the Po tomac, to be held at Brandy Sta tion, Culpeper county, Va., on the 9th August, under the auspices of A. P. Hill Camp No. 2, C. V. of Culpeper. Will you kindly aid us in convey ing to all of our old comrades in your community or of your former command, our invitation to them to be present. We are specially an xious to have a goodly delegation from every command that took part in any engagement at or near Bran dy, to aid in identifying localities of special interest, as we propose by setting np stones or other me morials to preserve for future gen orations the identity of localities ou this field of special historical interest. The Southern Railresd will sell round trip tickets for a little more than one fare for the occasion. We hope to make it one of interest and pleasure to all who may favor us

document.text: Circuit Court convened in special session here Monday, with Judge George J. Hundley presiding. The negro James Ford charged with the murder of his v ife at Pamplin, had his second trial, the former being a mistrial on account of some error m he clerk, at which trial he received a verdict of 15 years in the penitentiary. This verdict was set aside by the court and a new trial awarded. The jury rendered a verdict yesterday giving him 18 years in the peniieniiary. The ac cused was defended by Hon. W. C Franklin and Hon. E. W. Hubard and Mr. S. L. Ferguson and Hon. E Strode appeared for the Com- monwe, 1th. A stay of sentence has been allowed and the Supreme court will be asked to review the case. Court wiil remain iu session II the wek as the Judge is anx ious to clean up ihe criminal dock et.

document.text: Circuit Court commenced Moudat iu special session with Judge George J. Hundley presiding. This war the Judges first term here and hi.-, manner and disposition iu transact ing the business of the court was the subject of much favorable com ment. Court adjourned yesterday and the Judge left lor bis borne in Amelia, haviug finished all the fall terms of his courts. The Dumim-Forbs case was con tinued. There were some fifteen or twenty decrees entered in chancery,   ----------- - ------  High Priced Tobacco. Mr. Charles Burks, of Amherst county, sold last Friday in Lynch burg, at Rucker, Clark Tobacco .ompauys Warehouse, Martins. 1376 pounds of shipping tobacco which brought 166.05 making an average of over 12 per hundred pounds. The lots brought 4.50, 8.25, 10.75, 19.00 aud 20.00 These prices are very much higher than has been gotten heretofore this season and the sales attracted con siderable attention. It will be remembered by a great many of our readers that this firm got 46 per hundred for shipping tobacco, a year or so ago, for a Mr. Wheeler, of Nelson county which was the high est price ever known.

document.text: BUCKINGHAM DOTS. Miss Sarah E. OBrien died last Friday at her home in Buckingham. She was the youngest child of Judy A. and the late Frank OBrien. She was a pious Christian, a member of the Chestnut-Grove Baptist church. Her remains were interred at the old homestead. Mr. L. F. Jones has been appoint ed postmaster at New Store, in the place of Mr. A.S. Gilliam, who re signed and moved away. Judge George. J. Hundley has ap pointed the following gentlemen on  the Confederate pension board for I Buckingham county John T. Mc- I Kenna, A. C. Wood, Jno. C. Turner, I Dr. W. E. Pratt, and Wm. Williams. I A majority of the hoard met at the 1 Courthouse on Friday last, and de cided to meet again on May 15the Tuesday after county courtfor the prrpose of passing npon the claims of pensioners and transacting such j ot her business as may come tip. Circuit Court has been in session i since April 25lh. Much chancery  business was disposed of, and several Ismail damage cases. Judge Hund-  ley says that he will hold a special I term in order to clear up the bnsi- I mss. Court practically adjourned on Friday last.

document.text: B u ck in gh am . Ground bog weather still lingeis with us. It will be a many long weary year ere the believer in the accuracy of his hog-ships predictions can be otherwise persuaded. For if ever weather up held the believer in these forecast ings by the ground hog, the weath of the past month has supported this contention. It is a common remark that the weather only mod erates to turn colder. This morn ing dawns upon ns with evil fore bodingspromising more of the same old samer. Grippe has had full sway, in no sense being respector of persons but attacking the high and low the rich and ppor entering the mansion as well as the bedaubed hut. Laying his excru ciating hand upon the weak aud feeble as well as upon the strong and robust. And when we come to think of it, when his appearance made it is not soon forgotten We do not think we will soon con found the disease of bad cold and the once felt, never-to-be-forgotten grippe. We shall never reckon them as two distinct diseases. Mr. and Mrs. P. A. Forbes, who have been very unwell for quite awhile are just a little improved Though Mr. Forbes is expected fo go to Richmond on Wednesday next to consult a specialist in re gard to his sufferings. The two daughters of Mr. J. H Fitzgerald, Misses Fannie and Re beckah, who have been ill with pneumonia, at the Stonewall Jack- son school, at Abingdon, Virginia, where their mother, Mrs. Eva F itz gerald has been in attendance upon them for several weeks past, are so much better as to warrant the effort on the part of the mother to briug them home today. Mr. J. W. Word is confined to his room fiom the effects of severe carbuncles on his head and neck. He is reported to he no better this morning. Mr. P. A. Grigg is con fined to the house with severe cold and eruptions on his hands. He to unimproved this morning. Judge George J. Hundley, who was so unwell just as the term of Court, was winding up here, and who was confined to his bed for sev eral days thereafter, was so much improved that, in company, with Mrs. Hundley, he left on Friday last for his home near Farmville. Mrs. Virginia Hill, whose illness has been heretofore alluded to, is uow so weak as to be unable to sit up at all. Her age and the serious uature of her complaint, cause her friends and relatives to be very un easy about her. We learn with sincere pleasure that the condition of Mrs. Nannie F. Ellis, who has been quite ill with pneumonia, is somewhat improved. Mrs. Ada C. Gilliam is extremely ill with grippe at her horn 3 near Togs. Nearly all the members  her household are reported as more or less complaining, It seems tha . this disease goes through a familv when once it enters it. I take this opportunity of tender ing m y thanks to Mr. W. P. Ellis for letting me down so gently. It iB just like the couiteous gentle man he is to take a fellow to taw and then concede all of his eonten - tions. He and I have no quarrel witheach other any way. I will however endeavor to disabuse hi-, mind of an apparent lingering im pression that I undertook to criti cise the James r m r dist. Justice. I d this he is clear off. I would sim.Jy say that when a fellow undertakes to make a circle he necessarily touches on four lines, which form  square but his purpose is not to make the square bnt the circle. I therefore purposed to justify my coarse in the James River deer- hunting episode and,not to condemn my respected Jamas River associate justice. For I assure you this offi cer has my profonndest respect and ! esteem.

document.text: Lynn Saunders, the 9-year-old soil of L. B. Saunders, a fisherman, living on the boulevard between Newport News and Hampton, died with mark ed symptoms of hydrophobia. The boy was bitten by a mad dog two months ago, but little attention was paid to the matter until a few days ago, when he began to show symp toms of derangement, and at times suffered intense agony. Dr. T. J. Sims was called in and he at once pro nounced it a case of hydrophobia. It was then too late for the Pasteut or .any other treatment. The boy died after suffering which frequently- rendered him unconscious. Representatives of the Pressed Steel Car Company, of Pittsburg, were in Richmond to close a deal with the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad for 500 hopper-bottom coal cars. F. M. Robinson, for the Pittsburg company, said that the demand for cars had never been so brisk, and that orders were now on hand for nearly 45,000 cars. Because of the unprecedented re ceipts recently two of the hotels of Richmond announced that 750,000 will be spent in enlarging their build ings. The Richmond, which will erect in annex costing 50,000, has been ompleted only a short time. The jwner of Murphys Hotel will spend 400,000. The owner of this structure very recently built an annex at heavy ixpense. It is said that there have never been so many evidences of pros perity in the history of the hotels of Richmond. This goes to show that he condition of this section is excell ent. Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, president of the Jamestown Exposition Company, went to Washington to resume his efforts t? secure Congressional aid for the celebration of the tercentennial anni versary of the settlement of America lie expects President Roosevelt to aid the celebration . In the Circuit Court of Elizabeth City County, Peter1N. Phelps, presi dent of the Hampton Social Club, and Horace Davis, an employe of the club, were fined 200 each and given 60 days in jail for selling liquor to others than members of the club. It is ex pected that an appeal to the Supreme Court will be taken by the defendants. Capt. Frederipk Arhart died at his home in Henrico county, near Rich mond. He served in the Prussian army as a captain through the Franco- Prussian and Austro-Prussian wars He came to Amelia in 1865. He lived for a time in Washington.. He leaves a widow and five children. The residence of Andrew II. Hawk, near Bristol, was burned. Nothing was saved. The loss is 2,000 in surance, 500. A head-on collision between two trains oh the Danville and Western division of the Southern Railway at Stokesland, five miles above Danville resulted in the death of O. G. Minter ot Stockton, fireman, and Samuel Sta ples, colored, brakeman. Richard Hairston, a negro fireman, was severe ly injured and will probably die Charles Hundley, brakeman J. L. Boyd, engineer, and Conductor George T. Ware received painful injuries. Both trains were running fast when the accident happened. The collision was the result of a misunderstanding of orders. Judge Blackstone, in the Circuit Court, at Newport News, has granted an injunction restraining the Treas urer of Elizabeth City County from collecting taxes or otherwise interfer ing with the affairs of the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute Counsel for the school claimed that the property of the institute, which is valued at about r,000,000, is not subject to taxation. An argument up on a motion to make the injunction permanent will be heard later. The Commonwealths attorney asserts that the school has been violating the ex emption clause oi the constitution bj doing work for compensation for oth ers tham pupils of the school. While her husband slept Bettit Evans, colored, of Richmond, put twe bullets into his brain, killing him in stantly. The shooting seemingly fol lowed a quarrel, due to Evans habil of staying out late at night and then abusing his wife when he reached home. Governor Montague apopinted the following State Medical B-oard Drs Rawley W. Martin, of  Lynchburg Lewis E. Harvey, of Danville J. H Neff of Harrisonburg V. S. Culpeper, of Portsmouth W. W. Chaffin, of Pu laski City Paulus A. Irving and Lan- don B. Edwards, of Richmond. While polishing the handles of a pistol by rubbing it on her dress Mrs John Curlett, of Whealton, Lancaster county, accidentally shot herself. The ball entered her abdomen and passed through her body. The fight between the Lynchburg telephone company and the Southern Bell Company, which has been waged in Lynchburg for 10 years came to an end by the purchase by the Bell company of the franchise and equip ment of the home company. The price paid is not stated. Mrs. Cornelia Coe, wife of Rev. H. S. Coe, pastor of the Methodist Church at Mount Jackson, died at the .Strasburg Hospital. She had been ill for 10 months, and on Wednesday underwent an operation for the re-

Leading educators, headed by the Governor, met iir Richmond and form ed the Co-operative Education Com mission of Virginia, the objects ol which will be To secure a nine months public school term for every child. To bring a high school with in the reach of every child. Adequate normal school education. More ef ficient school supervision. Addition of agricultural and industrial-training to the curriculum. A library in every school. Suitable schools for defective and dependent classes. Educational associations in every community. Charles G. Forster, a brother oi Rudolph Forster, who is an assistant secretary to President Rooscvejt, snot and killed his wife, Eiizabcth Forster with a revolver and then killed lto self with the j same weapon. T.his was the verdict of the coroners jury summoned by Justice of the Charles S. Nichols. A committee from Virginia rcctnlly appointed by the Legislature to confei with a committee from Maryland tii the matter of settling differences existing between 1 lie two states re garding the oyster laws, left Norfolk on the pilot boat Relief for Annapolis, where the Maryland committee will be met and the points invojyed dis cussed in hopes of reaching an agreement. The Virginia committee consists of W. W . Sale, Norfolk L. Harding Walker, Northumberland county and L. II. Macbcn. Alexandria, of the Senate, and Moses Green, Fail quier county W. D. Cardwell, Han over county J. N. Stubbs, Gloucester county, and George Y. Hundley, Mat hews county, of the House. John Watson, colored, was arrested at Portsmouth, charged with the nuir der of George Gibson, colored. W at son, it is claimed, bad attempted t- kill the mother of Gibson and the on went to her rescue. Watson seized an iron bar and struck Gibson on the head. Death followed quickly. A committee from the Jamcstow Exposition Company left Norfolk for Wasliiington to ask the House com mittee of Congress for an appropria tion of 3,000,000 for the exposition. The speakers will be John Temple Graves, of Georgia Hon. John Goode and Joseph Bryan, of the Richmond Times, Gen. Fitzliugh Lee president of the company, will introduce the de legation. John Kennedy, who escaped from jail at Staunton on March 7, is still at large, although a reward of 500 has been offered for his recapture. Ken nedy, who was sentenced to hang fot  wrecking a train and killing the en-, giiiccr, escaped from jail in a sensa tional manner, only four days before the date set for his execution. It is believed that he made his way into West Virginia.

document.text: George Hundley Shreve, 85, of Route 1, Appomattox, died Thursday, Oct. 6, t 1963, at Lynchburg General Hospital. Born Nov. 17,1897, he was a son of Z the late Robert Lee and Melissa Shrove  of Spring Garden in Pittsylvania - County, Va. Orphaned at the age of six,  he was in the Methodist Orphanage for., two years when he was adopted by the , late Mr. and Mrs. Presley Hannah of- Appomattox County. He was married to the late Elbe Mae Hamlet. He was a retired fanner and owner of Ridgeway  Farm and was a member of Concord , Presbyterian Church, where he served as an elder for 61 years.  He is survived by a sister, Mis. Olbe Winstead, ReidsviDe, N.C., and several nieces and nephews.   Funeral services were conducted at 11 a.m. Saturday at Concord Presbyterian Church in Charlotte County burial followed in the church, cemetery.  .v Robinson Funeral Home was in i charge of arrangements. DerisULThompeea . Daniel H. Thompson, formerly of Appomattox, died Friday morning at the age of 59 in Dover, Del. He is being  buried in Delaware on Wednesday atV 100. Thompson was a retired U.S. Air Force Sgt. . He is survived by his wife, Florence Ford Thompson, one daughter, Patricia  Ann Thompson, seven brothers andi sisters. George H. Thompson of Appomattox, Fred E. Thompson ofy Brookneal, A lta T. Evans ofJ Appomattox, Amy T. Mosley of! Richmond, Elizabeth J. Thompson ofv Appomattox, Erma Bluther of Balti- more, Mary T. Garrett of Evergreen..?

document.text: _ ____ __ ________ offered to any person all day services were held there Iin cers, for the capture of with a fine dinner served on the grounds. Wyatt Pendleton who was mentioned in last weeks paper as having made his escape from jail here came back and j gave himself up voluntarily and is now in jail again. Hon. John B. Boatwright has been declared the nominee of the Democratic party for the Legislature by the chairman of the Democratic committee of both Cumberland and Buckingham counties. Dr. P. jE. Tucker who was the opponent of Mr. Boat wright in the late primary has served notice of contest and the contest iB likely to come before Judge Geo. J. Hundley for trial at the coming term of September court. Mr. Paul Elcan who has been a law student in Washington, D. C., is in this county visit ing relatives and friends. Mr. George Bondurant, of Alabama, and Prof. A. L. Bon durant, of Missippi, are visit ing at their old homes here. Dr. Taylor preached two ex-1 cellent sermons at the Baptist! church here on Sunday and he will preach all the week. Fhere was good attendance at both I services but preaching was going on at other churches at j the same time and the crowd j was somewhat divided. Dr.j Taylor has just concluded a meeting at Antioch church. The County School Board is called to meet here on Tuesday August 23rd. There is to be a new school building erected at Arvouia, but the location has not yet been determined on and the Trustee Electoral Board will meet there about the matter of locating the school. If high water does not fol low the dry spell we are hav ing the corn on low lands is likely to produce well as the ears are large and the stalks are green looking, in striking and refreshing contrast with the parched and dry fields of corn on high land. I sold wheat at 1.25 a bushel and corn at 1 a bushel the past week, but if conditions do not change soon as regards to weather, prices are sure to ad vance. The pries of gasolene has gone down to 25c on the local market. I was told an instance where a drummer was travel ing in a near-by county recent- _ ly when his car caught on fire from leaking gasolene and was

document.text: the iron was hot and they sent Mr. Hubbard Baird to Norfolk to .bring back a truck for use on the roads of this county. It is being told as a joke on a lady in this county that a man who is a semi-idiot came to her house and when she met him at the door instead of tell ing what he wanted he follow ed her in the house then she became frightened, and sent for the men folks out in the field and when they came past haste, they found the lady holding her gun on the man whom they at once recognized as the feeble minded young man from a neighbors house. She said it was the most strenu ous time of her life when she stood there holding that gun on the man. People who are beforehanded got busy ordering a good sup ply of sugar last- week and when the expected raise takes place it is likely to find many people with a supply on hand. The superintendent of a coal mine in West Virginia sent for a man from this county who has mined for years and told him to bring all the old time miners with him who wanted work. It is said that the war tax has been taken off the Rail road tickets and also off of other things. Hon John B. Boatwright in writing to me from his seat in the legislature sends his re garde to his friends here. The people living near St. Andrews school house and church have decided to start to digging a well for use of both school and church, they propose to get the work done by voluntary iabor by the men each one contributing so many daos work. Messrs. H. C. Glover, Willie Patteson and F. R. Moon are among those who have recent ly shipped tobacco to Lynch burg. Mr. E. W. Hubard und wife have come to the court bouse and are boarding at the Pear son hotel. Mrs. J. D. McArthur leaves this week for her home at St. Paul, N. C. Some ice has been harvested but it was not very thick. There was a threat made tu take a post office from a mer chant because he was a demo crat and he said that was all right his partner was a repub lican and he would get the ap pointment. The burning of the dormitory at Blackstone Female Institute and then the burning of the Military school for boys there caused considerable loss to Buckingham boys and girls. Miss Connor, of Diilwyn, was one of the lady Btudents there and Mr. Russell Moon Jr , was one of the boys there from thiB county. It is truly remarkable how much more readily negroes who have some education will subscribe to a newspaper than white people. Cattle in the northern part of the county have been mak ing their living on blue grass up to this time and there has been ao snow as yet to cover the grass up. Turkeys for breeding purpos es have been selling at 10 for the toms and 5 for hens. Dress goods have come down considerably lower than the cnee and considerably lower in price. Dr. Thomas Hugs Lacy filled bis appointments ai St. An drews Emanuel churches on Fndiy and Sunday respective ly and was looking much better than he did when he wee here last month. Judge George Jefferson Hundley will succeed himself a judge of this Judicia.t circuit He is 84 years old

document.text: Circuit Court The following business was disposed of by Judge Hundley last week. Ordered that J.. B. Marshall and his bondsmen be relieved of the custody of P. H. Holly cross who was heretofore ad judged a lunatic, the court de ciding he was erroneously so adjudged. Rosser Milling Co. vs Va. C, C Co. continued to 5th day of Oct.damage suit. N. A. Davis  o. vs. T. J Ligon, case continued to 4th day of Oct.to establish land boundry. Adaline A. Scruggs and Mila Mays are added to the pension roll of Va. The following fiduciary ac counts wete settled T WJJJer, guardian W E Hannah, admr P M Hannah H W McKinney admr. T G Thorpe W J Walker admr. Margaret Harvey W Trent, admr. M E Pankey J O Evans guardian Sussie Evans. Sundry licenses granted for the sale of soft drinks  Com. vs Kinuey Qalhoun plea of guilt? court fixed his punishment at two years in the penitentiary for shooting. L. W. Thornton was fined 10 for his failure to attend court as a witness. Odell Howerton qualified as guardian cor his infant child L. H Hicks,8 T. Brown and Lloyd Page were appointed trustees for Spout Spring Mis sion school property. F. O. Jones, E. R Jones, J.H. Robertson and J. B. Chilton,ap pointed trustees for Salem ch. property J. B. Chilton wasalBO appointed, trustee for circuit parsonage property at Concord. P. C. Walker c vs R Ger trude Scruggs c continued. A H Howerton, 8 WHarvey, S E Anderson,J W Coleman, jr, H W Ferguson, J H Marshall J W C Martin, J H Robertson, A B Baldwin, J A Stratton and J D Bondurant, the grand jury returned the following indict ments Ernest Lee, manufacturing iquor bail 500. George Glover, manufactur ing liquor bail 500. Banks Robertson, transport ing liquor bail 500. Henderson Vaughan, trans porting liquor convicted, .30 days in jail and fined 50. Ap pealed and bailed in the sum ofr500 Sundry chancry decrees were enterred.

No. 237, to provide a special road law for Ixsudoun County. Patron, Del egate Noland. No. 238, authorizing the town of Shenandoah with the Counties of Pag and Rockingham, Jointly to acquire the bridge across the Shenandoah River at this point. Patrons, Delegates Leedy Rolston and F. J. Wright. No. 239, amending the road law of Caroline County. Patron, Delegate Beale. No. 240, authorizing Prince George County to accept from E. I. du Pont de Nemours t Company a contribution of 25,000 for the construction of a road from City Point to Petersburg, and to borrow 40,000 more for this purpose. Patron, Delegate Harrison. No. 241, authorizing the Board of Su pervisors of Albemarle County to erect toll gates on macadam roads in that county. Patrons, Delegates Page and Pitts. No. 249, repealing the act establish ing a dispensary at Farmville and pro viding that no liquor license shall hereafter be granted in Prince Edward I County. Patron, Delegate Winston. No. 250, providing for the taking of a special school census in Bland Magisterial District of Prince George County. Patron, Delegate Harrison. No. 251, authorizing the University of Virginia to enter Into a contract with Dr. William E. Hopklnf, of New York City, In regard to a conditionll donation and to enter into contracts of a similar nature with others. Pa tron, Delegate Pitts. No. 252, authorizing the School Board of District No. 5, Page County, to borrow money and issue bonds therefor. Patron, Delegate Leedy. No. 259,jiamendlng the charter of tbe city of Richmond so as to provide life tenure for firemen. Patrons. Delegates Price, Fuller, Jones, Hobson and Myers. No. 263, amending the road law of Giles County. Patron, Delegate Shu mate. No. 264, authorizing the Board of Supervisors of King and Queen Coun ty to borrow 5,000 for road improve ment. Patron, Delegate Hundley. No. 265, amending the act authoriz ing the Warrenton and Fairfax Turn pike Company to take possession of the turnpike leading from near War renton to Fairfax Courthouse. Pa trons, Delegates Tiffany and Meetze. No. 271, authorizing the Boards of Supervisors of Alleghany, Bath and Highland Counties to appropriate money for the purchase of motor trucks to be used in building and keeping in repair roads in these coun ties. Patron, Delegate Stephenson.

document.text: I FARM V1LLK.  iiw The eons of veterans of Farmville and he surrounding country h ive p had a preliminary meeting to or- K ganize a local camp. Forty-five I names have already been enrolled I and no doubt the number will soon I pach 100. Capt. S. W. Paulett  p leads in the movement as he always Ip does when Dixie s to be remember- I ed and honored. Generally the sons  take the name o the camp of the veterans and if so in  this instance the camp will be known as Thornton-Pickett camp. Capt. J. T Thornton went out from this county as Captain oi the Prince Edward troops which was after- wards known as Oo. E, 3rd Vir ginia Cavalry, was promoted to Lieu6nant Colonel an t fell morU ally wounded on the bloody fiel i ol Sharpsbug. His remains were broug.it here and buried at the old home in Cumberland. Virginia R never had a better citizen and the 1 Confederacy had no bnver soldier.  Tread lightly upon his grave ye men of genius for he was your kins- K man, glean clean his grave ye men of goodness for he was your brol- p her. Bev. Andrew Allan, the new pas tor of the Presbyterian church, preached his first sermon as such on Ej! last Sunday, taking as his text Ro- K  mans 15 29, and delivered a strong sermon which was attentively liaten- tively listened to by the large con- I legation present to hear him. He is a native Scotchman, has s.me- R.- thing of the brogue, but is a plea- I sant and forceful speaker. Bev. S. G. Hatcher, D. D., former pastor of the Fa mviile Methodist  church, was in town recently, and as is hts wont went from home to home and square to square shaking hands right and left. In this most dssirable accomplishment he is past master. He makes friends wher ever he goes and then holds to them I  with hooks of ste-d. I confess that I dont understand the silence prevailing among the friends of Turnbull and Watson as pirants for a seat in Congress. The 1 primary will soon be oo and yet nothing doing. It may, however,  . be the stillness -that precedes the Iv. etTin. M mt of the farmers were ready to  plant tobacco on the 27th bnt the rain failing io come the work was postpond. One of the most suc cessful of i hem said,  The rain will - come in lima He is not oidyal farmer but a philosopher, and bet I ter still, a Christian. An adjourned session of West I Hanover Presbytery was held in the Farmville Presbyterian church on  the afternoon of the 29th of May when Bev. Andrew Allan, after the ususl examination, was received as a member of the body. The minis- teis prevent were Revs. Leps, Hud son, King and Graham with two elders of the Farmville Churoh. Mr. Allan w 11 he installed in the near fuure. Mesdames D. T. Elam, J . R. Mar tin and J . H. Lewis went as repre sentatives from the Methodist Church to Charlottesville to attend a Misson Union of that Church. Mr. George Farrar has been taken I to Richmond for special treatment at St, Lukes.  Mrs. Wadei8 visiting friends in  Albemarle. Judge Hundley has been it nome R during the week. iVi W ith all this fuss going on in p political circles not a word is heard -, from Jude Watkins, and surely he I H wouldnt relish being spokin of as a I  retired po itician. There must be  many a had fight in him yet. Hr began his career when the storm r raged forieualj- The Gnn Club is having a high old   time and the members are enjoying  I the eport immensely. Sanford still   champion with no one treading on  his heels. And yet many of the boys are doing well. A friend irom Cumberland brought your correspondent a speci men of bam just fire years old and it was more than fit lor the gods. Bnt the mystery is that any body could keep such bam for five years i and not eat it all. it is not generally known and yet I am told it is a fact that on 100 acres of Buckingham lands more corn was grown in one season than I on any other 100 acres the count y over. document.text: Hundley Spring Notes. Miss Clara Driskill has returned home from the Hill City where she has been visiting friends. Little Misses Aubrey and Trena Martin, of Lowry are visiting their grand-parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Martin, of this community.. The young people of this vicinity are planning a fishing party, for their holliJay sport. Mr. George Harvey, of this neigh borhood who has been sick for some time is improving. The recent rains will put the farmees out in preparing their corn and tobacco land. J.

document.text: Here and there in tha Grand Old County. Mrs. Nancy M. Lonaree died last Thursday evening after a loug_ ill ness, and was buried Saturday near Omohu uuro. Mr. William Joues, aged 74 years, died at his home m Warren last Saturday, and was buried at Axtell on Monday by Rev. Asa Driscoll. Archie, sou of Mr. J . S. Rush, cf Euonville, is ill with malarial fe ver. Dr. Mitchell hopes to have him out in a short while. Capt. George Lane, aged 80 years, was buried at Rock Island on iast Su l.day. Dr. Paul Whitehead will preach a Glenuiore on the 3rd Saturday and Sunday in May. The people are iopking forward to his visit with great interest. Dr. Whitehead is a great preacher. Circuit Court has been in session several days. Judge Hundley pre siding. Many minor cases were tried. Hon. Edmund Hu bard received the nomination for the Constitu tional Convention from the countjqs of Cumberlaptjtid Buckingham at rwllemocratio Convention. Miss Bernice Miller, who has been visiting relatives in Lynch burg for the past month, returnee to her home at Glenuiore last week. About three years ago Mrs Hart ley Cabell nee Logan presented the village of Buckingham with a maguificent library of several thous and volumesand the Library As sociation continues lo add new books time to time. Next Friday will give an en tertainment in the Courthouse for the beuefit of this library, Misses Lula Joues and Bertna Camden are busily engaged iu train ing the young people for a Chil drens Day Service at Glenuiore on the 4th Sunday iu May. Mrs. T. S. Joues, of Axtell, is quite ill. Little Susie, daughter of W. T. Camden, Axtell, is slowly improving after a weeks illness. A citizens meeting last week en dorsed Colonel James Lvous for the Constitutional. Convention, and Col onel Lyons has registered his name at tile county clerks office, so as to get his name on the ticket. He will have the support of the Repub licans.

document.text: Consequent on the eitremely cool I weather of last week there hasl been much sickness, especially I among the children and a Mr. I Shoemaker lost one of his children. I Dr. L.G. Morris had the misfor- tn ne to loose a valuable horse. Mr. John Cobb near Slate River I Miils has been in a critical condi- 1 tion for the last few days from the kick of a mule. His skull was broken and he was rendered un conscious. Drs. Morriss and Mit chell attended him. Miss Eddie Chappell came, upj I from Richmond on Monday and I was met by her brothers at White Hall and taken home. She was in  a very weak condition and had to 1 be lifted from the cars to her car riage, but the operation recently I performed is said to be entirely suc- I cessful and it is hoped her recov- I ery of health may only be a qnes- 1 tion of time. Dr.. George Beni Johnson was her surgeon. An effort will be made to prevent! any but Democrats voting in the I coming primaries of that party and a committee is to formulate the question, or questions to be asked each sovereign when he offers to deposit his ballot. In some in stances it conld be seen that at the la 8 t,primrry held in this county more votes were cast than there  were registered Democrats at the  precinct. The average citizen is looking  forward to June conrt as the time j when he may meet his frsends as  he did in days of yore, when we had county courts each month. Why is it that the country newspapers I do not inaugurate a move to get the courts re-established ? I see that long headed Andersonville correspondent is reminding the peo- 1 pie to. see to it that no man goes to the Legislature who is not for Judge Hundley for Circuit Judge, and indeed he is right, when he urges the importance of retaining suoh a man in office as Judge Hnnd- ley is. Mr. L. T. Fones had ten head of  sheep killed by dogs last week. What has become of the dog tax ? Mr, Elcan, the assessor in District number oue has taken my tax list but he did not ask if I had a dog. Is it that they do not make a list of the dogs every year ? Dr. Samuel R. Glover has come home from Richmond, where he has been attending the Medical College of Virginia.

document.text: Chap Notes. The condition of Mr. Richard Woolridge is more hopeful, he is im proving rapidly. Prayer meeting services will be held in Central on next Sunday forenoon at 10 oclock, condncted by Mr. E. G. Harvey. Miss Clara Driskill of Hundleys Springs, and Miss Maud Driskill of this vicinity called on this place on last Saturday afternoon. Mr. Gilmore Moses is suffering from an attack of La Grippe. The Ladies Aid Society met in Central church on last Saturday night. The Society was entertained by recitatins by Misses Maud Dris kill, Lizzie Harvey and Master Borne Driskill. Miss Lizzie Harvey paid over 10 cents to the.Treasurer, Mr. J. Arthur Moses, made by work for benefit of Society and Miss Annie Branch paid over sixty-five cents. All are very anxious to finish pay ing off the chhrch debt. The next meeting will be held Saturday, Feb ruary the eighth. Mr. Clarence Moses of Rolling Hill visited his parents here on Tues day last. Mr. George Harvey lost one of fiis oxn on last Saturday. It dropped dead while hauling a load of ties to Appomattox Depot. The schools are well attended since the holidays and the pupils are doing good work. Mr. Arthur Moses was struck by a falling log on last Wednesday after- n. His left wrist was very badly sprained it is not so painful as it as been. Miss Nora Lee entertained her friends at her home on last Saturday
